title: What are reasons not to move to Silicon Valley? - Quora

response.answer_text: Unless you’re working in tech, it probably doesn’t make sense to live in the Bay Area. And, even then, if you don’t have family here, nor entrepreneurship ambitions, you should try to look for a job in another location. Your lifestyle would be of higher quality. Pros of living in the Bay Area: The people. This is in first position for a reason: living here, you’ll meet passionate, brilliant, high energy, ambitious, creative people from everywhere in the World. It’s hard to describe how invigorating that is, and how much of a difference it makes in your life.The ecosystem. If your goal, short or long term, is to build a tech company, the Bay Area is probably the best place to do it in the US, or even in the World. Sure, your burn rate will be 2–3x than if you went somewhere else, but you’ll also have access to a lot more capital, and talent.The salary. This one applies almost only to software engineers, and not to all of them. Sure, even the average salary for an entry-level engineer seems high here (~$110k), but that’s counter balanced by California’s high income tax, and the insane rent. Think $3k/month for a 1BR. But you can have a very high salary as a SE here (think $300k+ all included).The weather. It’s very pleasing to live somewhere sunny all year long.Cons of living in the Bay Area: It’s unsafe. I have a friend who got his car’s window smashed every week, 4 weeks in a row. According to Neighborhood Scout, SF is in the top 2% most dangerous cities in the US. New York is in the top 27%. There are many neighborhoods in SF that are pretty scary, both at night and in the day.It’s very dirty, and SF’s homelessness is sky high. Not making any value judgment here, there probably are systemic issues etc etc, just pointing at a fact: there are about 10,000 homeless people in SF’s 47 square miles. Passing by 2 people, passed out on the sidewalk, with needles in their arm, on your morning walk, having someone pantless, smoking crack on your subway ride, or sitting next to you and starting to masturbate when you take your coffee, are not the best experiences (not even talking of routinely stepping onto human feces).Also, SF’s ideology can have you run into a lot of trouble if you dare even talk about this huge issue, like that time Twitter fired their head of VR, one day into the job, because they found out he’d written a rant on FB 4 years before, about how bad homelessness had become in SF. This is the reason I’m writing this post anonymously.Its infrastructure is crumbling. SF’s roads are in such a bad state that all the shaking sometimes makes it hard to use your phone in a car. The city is inundated, and massive potholes form almost every year, when it rains a bit more than usual. In 2015, a three-story lamp post, made of iron, badly damaged by urine, collapsed onto an occupied car.It’s expensive. I mentioned it before, but the rent and taxes are crazy high, which makes it impossible for most people to build a family here (the reason why there are so few kids in the city). The situation is mostly due to rampant NIMBYism, basically land-owners who have a vested interest in the housing supply being constrained, so it can not meet demand and sees its price appreciate, blocking all construction with stupid reasons like “the charm of the neighborhood” or “not enough parking spots”.It’s monocultural. I, for one, working in tech, tend to like it. Anywhere you go, you’ll meet smart engineers, working in big companies, telling you off-the-record stories about what they’ve been working on, or the shady hack they used to go around an issue. But if you’re not in tech, it can become tiring, very quickly, to meet almost only this kind of people.a cool thing about having coffee with a friend on market street is when a guy sits down next to you and starts masturbating— à² _à²  (@MikeIsaac) March 19, 2017

Why would you not move to Silicon Valley? Here are some cautionary bullet points, but I’ll also include perspective on what makes it great below: Don’t move here if you want to get rich quick. “overnight success” here really takes a minimum of 10 - 20 years - if you get it at all.Don’t move here if you want strong work-life balance. This is a place that emphasizes working hard - the joke is “people here will work 80 hours a week (in a start up) so they don’t have to work 40 (at a ‘desk job’)”Don’t move here if you want a good “night life”. Sure there’s great music here and plenty of good food + cocktails, but the bar scene and the club scene don’t hold a candle to cities like NYC, London, Tokyo or even L.A.Don’t move here if you like an active dating scene. I’ve been out of the singles’ game for a while, but what I remember - and what I hear still - is that everyone seems to have a chip on their shoulder, no one wants to compromise, and throw on top of that most people dress like they don’t give a shit about fashion / looking good and it just makes the dating scene “challenging”.Don’t move here if you’re intolerant. Just looking within 50 feet of where I’m sitting I see white people, black people, asian people, mixed people. They are christian, muslim, atheist, buddhist and somethings I’ve never heard of. You’ll hear English, Spanish, Chinese, Hindi, Tagalog, Farsi, and any number of languages anywhere you go. If you don’t say ‘murica ironically, this place isn’t for you.Don’t move here if you like to smoke cigarettes. You can smoke weed on the street and no one will look at you twice, but smoke a cigarette and everyone will look at you like you just kicked a puppy.Don’t move here if you don’t like Tech. If you hate tech or tech culture, you’re gonna HATE IT HERE.Here are some reasons to move here There is amazing opportunity. All the big companies are here, and there are startups everywhere where you can try new things, craft your skill and maybe even get lucky.There are brilliant people here. Sure some can be jerks, but that’s everywhere. The reality is that some of the brightest minds in the world are here and you can learn new things just sitting at a coffee shop and eavesdropping, not to mention the challenge and inspiration that comes from working alongside certifiable geniuses.The day life is awesome. There’s water everywhere, hiking, wine country, running trails, beaches and mountains / lakes a few hours drive away. The need to “travel” for vacation is dramatically reduced if you take advantage of what’s right next to you.The food is amazing. I’ve been all over the world and had amazing food and it doesn’t get better than here. Sorry NYC, I know you like to think you have better food, and I’ll give you that your presentation is nicer, but you want farm-to-table Chinese food? you can get that next to the organic Mexican place that’s across from the new pop-up restaurant featuring middle-eastern fusion tapas which does chicken and waffles at night. They're all delicious.Pot is legal. Enough said.The tech scene can’t be beat. It saturates everything here and, if you’re into technology and “futurism” it’s like living in a god-damn sci-fi novel sometimes.
